docs.text: seen may 2 , 1998 at 3 : 40 p . m . at the crossgates cinema 18 , theater #13 , with chris wessell and sean o'shea for $5 .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: [theater rating : * * * 1/2 : very good sound , picture , and seats]
docs.label: negative

docs.text: the big-budget , mega-hype " event " movie is becoming so trendy now it is becoming a weekly routine instead of a seasonal one .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: gluttony is hollywood's favorite sin , but it is the movie-goers who pay the price by being dealt the same things over and over on an ever-worsening basis .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: " lost in space " is the latest such offering - a film so poor it would be twice as good if it were mediocre .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: it's made up of every element of science fiction , but at no time does it evoke the slightest amount of wonderment the genre was meant for .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: audiences' attention spans are rapidly decreasing and as is the trend with such films , this one opens with a fast-paced space battle which serves not only as the most interesting scene in the film ( probably because it has " star wars " written all over it ) , but as the producers' way of showing off their budget through the special effects .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: battle scenes are worthless without tension , and since we have no idea what the setting is it's impossible to care about anything that happens .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: in essence , the entire segment works like a teaser for an arcade game , not a piece of filmmaking .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: we meet the robinson family - a family of five that does not get along but has been chosen to act on earth's behalf in effort to find another planet worthy of colonization due to the exhausting of our natural resources .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: each member of the family has a special trait and personality , and yet none of them seem like actual people .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: professor john robinson ( hurt ) is the intelligent , quiet leader who has devoted so much time to his work his family and marriage are suffering without his realizing it ( it's obvious what role this aspect will play ) .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: of course this is all established through extremely melodramatic scenes such as the children and parents arguing and bickering among themselves and with each other , while the necessary problems are " resolved " at the right moments .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: the only thing worse than the screenplay is the fact it's presented in a completely serious manner without a trace of satire , and is so pathetic it's laughable .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: the first act is not a building of a story , but a juxtaposition of scenes that serve no purpose other than to plug in all the required elements ( such as plot , conflict , and characterization - god forbid ! ) .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: we're provided with the minimum amount possible of these elements to keep the film from being completely silent .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: in fact , it might as well be since the dialogue is virtually non-existent .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: yes , the characters do speak , but they do not talk .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: they say things that only relate to the conflict , but they never really interact ( unless it's the cartoony flirting scenes between arrogant major don west ( leblanc ) and uptight , unemotional judy robinson ( graham ) ) .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: it's amazing that after an hour of trite dialogue and generic plot devices that so little happens .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: eventually the pacing rapidly increases , but the amount of genuine interest does not .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: the story finally gains some prospective by living up to its title as the robinsons find themselves lost in space after narrowly managing to defeat dr . smith ( oldman ) , the cartoony villain , and his plans for sabotage .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: what ensues is a series upon series of completely unrelated conflicts .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: the first such scene takes place on an abandoned spaceship and what ensues could best be described as " alien " -lite .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: the story changes again when the robinsons crash land on an alien planet and must act quickly to escape it and survive .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: but there's never any real notion of suspense here because the script constantly wanders aimlessly .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: plotlines are developed , but each becomes totally irrelevant as the story changes from scenario to scenario .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: the atmosphere attempts to be surreal by incorporating time travel and various time paradoxes , but it's presented in such a ridiculous way it's utterly boring .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: by the time the last act rolls around , there is no sense of a payoff building .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: the ending does not go out on a high note with any kind of climax , instead , it seems to come to a sudden halt ( but at least it ends at all ) .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: " lost in space " is major film production at its worst .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: it's frightening that a film so poorly written , directed , and acted might be considered mainstream entertainment .
docs.label: negative
